stream_context.summary: Kaze, while visibly sick, works almost entirely on sketching Part 2 of the main overworld (the segment that links Part 1 and Part 3) for Return to Yoshi’s Island.  The session is dominated by layout decisions—how the player will be gated after Bowser 1, how Course 3 and Bowser 1 entrances should read, and which traversal mechanic (bridge, raft, Yoshi-ride, Dory) finally makes sense.  Numerous side-topics arise: collision re-writes, an upcoming Squarespace sponsorship, the possibility of a future PC port, and Nintendo legal worries.
level: High-level talk of remaining overworld parts (Part 4, Part 5)

development_findings.summary: 15 of ~17 main courses are already finished; focus has shifted to completing the multi-part overworld and a few side levels before polishing and release.
development_findings.quote: “We have 15 courses done, and now we're doing the overworld, and then a couple more side levels… this is like a final stretch.”

development_findings.summary: Part 2 must block the player until Bowser 1 is cleared.  Earlier idea (paying a Yoshi 100 coins to repair a bridge) is scrapped as thematically weak.
development_findings.quote: “Yoshis aren't really known for repairing bridges… you just saved him and now he wants money from you.  This feels wrong.”

development_findings.summary: New gating solution: a chained Dory in a lake.  After Bowser 1 the freed Yoshis appear; one claims to have freed Dory, letting Mario ride her to Part 5.
development_findings.quote: “Dory chained to a wall in the lake… after beating the first Bowser the Yoshi on Dory’s back says he freed her with his mighty behind.”

development_findings.summary: Engine now has a full collision rewrite that eliminates Mario 64’s infamous invisible walls.
development_findings.quote: “My engine actually doesn't have invisible walls anymore… I reworked how Mario handles collision altogether.”

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans a small ‘mineshaft’ set-piece: moles mining a wall and asking for 100 coins to speed up, establishing overworld coin utility.
development_findings.quote: “So exhausted from hitting rocks… but for 100 coins I wouldn't mind speeding up a bit over here.”

development_findings.summary: Considering Wiseguy’s static-recomp PC port as the eventual path to 144 FPS PC release; porting RTYI to that codebase would be easier than vice-versa.
Long-term contingency: if Nintendo issues a strike he will swap all Nintendo assets for original ones and sell the game.
development_findings.quote: “I'm half hoping Nintendo shuts me down so I have to exchange all the assets for non-Nintendo assets so I can actually sell it.”

development_findings.summary: Squarespace sponsorship (6 videos/3 months) will be leveraged by producing one quick video per actor rework and a possible 3-hour ‘All Invisible Walls’ video.
development_findings.quote: “I'm just gonna make a video about every single actor rework… way too much money to pass up on.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze is extremely ill (vomiting, headaches) but streams anyway; credits Zeina for soup and tea and jokes about ‘cooties’.
context_findings.quote: “I got cooties from Zeina… yesterday I vomited like six times before 10 a.m.”

context_findings.summary: He dismisses formal game-design education, arguing the field is too young and prefers self-directed study—citing ‘Thinking, Fast and Slow’.
context_findings.quote: “Studying game design is relatively pointless… it’s like physics before the ancient Greeks.”

context_findings.summary: Legal attention from Nintendo seems unrelated to whether he monetises content; he perceives less pressure now despite Patreon and YouTube income.
context_findings.quote: “I had the most legal attention on me while I was not making money off of what I was doing.”

context_findings.summary: Wants to avoid releasing immediately after content completion to reduce Nintendo DMCA risk and to time marketing properly.
Mentions the added difficulties of parenthood—baby transmits illnesses—which now affects his work rhythm.
context_findings.quote: “I have a baby, and the baby sneezed on her hand and then put her hand in my mouth.”

biobak.summary: Active in chat brainstorming; suggests a 3-hour auto-generated video visualising every collision triangle, which Kaze adopts for sponsorship content.
biobak.quote: “Oh my god, Biobak, that’s such a good idea… that’s the freest video ever.”

zeina.summary: Provides personal care while Kaze is sick and is jokingly blamed for giving him the illness.
Offers small thematic ideas (e.g., Dory solution) during the gating discussion.

key_stories.title: Bridge vs. Dory Gating Pivot
key_stories.summary: Part 2 originally locked players behind a payable bridge repair, but Kaze found the concept forced and off-brand.  Over the stream he brainstorms alternatives with chat, ultimately settling on a chained Dory freed by returning Yoshis.
key_stories.challenge: Create a lore-consistent, readable gate that only opens after Bowser 1.
key_stories.process: Discarded coin bridge, debated rafts/Yoshi ride, weighed thematic links, accepted chat’s Dory-idea, and drafted cut-scene/dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: Design notes now state a chained Dory appears in the lake; once Yoshis return, Dory is freed and rideable, connecting to Part 5.
key_stories.key_quote: “Dory chained to a wall… after beating the first Bowser the Yoshi on her back says he freed her.”

key_stories.title: Invisible-Wall Visualization Video
key_stories.summary: Needing six quick sponsorship videos, Kaze and Biobak devise an automated tool that pans through every level, highlights collision walls, and records hours of footage—turning a technical curiosity into paid content.
key_stories.challenge: Deliver six Squarespace videos in three months without derailing game work.
key_stories.process: Leverage existing collision rewrite; Biobak proposes auto-recording tool; Kaze earmarks coding it later and dedicating a full video to it.
key_stories.outcome: Confirmed plan for a ‘3-hour invisible wall movie’ plus actor rework videos, securing sponsorship payment while marketing the hack.
key_stories.key_quote: “That’s gonna save me so much time… I’m gonna program this later and make the video.”

key_stories.title: Collision System Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Earlier in development, Kaze rewrote Mario’s collision to remove invisible walls—both a quality-of-life and design freedom upgrade.
key_stories.challenge: Original SM64 collision creates unfair invisible barriers, hurting new level layouts.
key_stories.process: Re-engineered collision handling, tested on hardware, removed legacy checks.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI levels no longer rely on invisible walls; Kaze can design open spaces without worrying about unseen blockers.
key_stories.key_quote: “I haven’t hit invisible walls in months—it’s because I reworked how Mario handles collision altogether.”
